feathers.
Q. How doth man bear Gods image in keeping this Commandment?
A. That he Phil. 4.11. content himſelf with the things he hath.
Q. GOD hath al-ſufficiency in himſelf.
A. So hath Phil. 4, 18. a Chriſtian.
Q. How can that be?
A. He 2 Joh. 9. hath the Father and the Son.
Q. What then?
A. And 1 Cor. 3.2. therewith all things.
Q. Then he need not rob others?
A. No Gen. 44.8..
Q. Why ſo?
A Becauſe Phil. 4.18 none can give him more then he hath.
Q. How ſo?
A. He Ibid, hath all.
Q. How can that be?
A. He 2 Ioh. 9. hath him that hath all.
Q. As how?
A. In Jam. 2 5 faith.

Q. What's the fifth particular?
Sect. 30
A. The eighth Exod. 20 16. Commandment declares.
Q. What's the ſumme of it?
A. Not to Mica. 7.6 debaſe others.

Q. How doth one man
debaſe another?
A. By Act. 6, 13 bearing falſe witneſſe againſt another.
Q. VVhy doth one man bear falſe witneſse against another?
A. Every Zech, 11 13. man doth it for his own advantage.
Q. Is this in uſe at this day?
A. It was 1 Tim. 6 3, 4. never out of uſe.
Q. Where?
A. Amongſt Pſa. 14, 2 men.
Q. VVhy?

A. Becauſe Gen. 4. 5 every man is apt to ſee anothers wiſdom, and power,
and honour, and holineſſe, to ſtand in his way.
Q. VVhat doth he do to take it out of the way?
A. He Gal. 4.17 ſtains it with evil report.
Q. VVhoſe honour and glory is moſt ſtained in the world?
A. Chriſts Mat, 11, 19..
Q. And whoſe too?
A. Thoſe Mat, 11, 18. that are Chriſts.
Q. And whoſe elſe?
A. Thoſe Mat, 27, 4. that are moſt innocent.
Q. VVhy ſo?

A. Becauſe Iſa. 24, 23. their
Sun out ſhines the light of others.
Q. Sect. 31 What's the ſixth particular?
A. That the Exod. 20, 17. tenth word in the law ſhews.
Q. What's the mind of GOD in it?
A. That Ibid. there be no coveting.
Q. Of what?
A. Of Ibid. outward things.
Q. How mean you?
A. Such ibid. things as are in others poſſeſsion.
Q. How doth this tenth differ from the ſeventh Commandment?
A. That forbids robbing, This coveting.
Q. What is robbing?
A. An 1 King. 21, 15. applying to our ſelves that which is not our own.
Q. What is coveting?
A. A wiſhing 1 King. 21, 2. and longing to have the things of others to apply it to our ſelves.
Q. What's the occaſion of it?
A. Twofold.
Q. Name the firſt?
A. An 1 King. 21, 5, 6. undervaluing of what is reckoned our own.
Q. What is to be reckoned as our own?
A. That which Eccleſ. 3, 13. is given to us of GOD.
Q. Shew it in an instance?
A. As ſuppoſe houſe, wife, ſervants, &c.
Q. What of them?
A. They Iſa. 30, 23, 24, 25. are the gifts of GOD, for our uſe.
Q. VVhat's the ſecond occaſion?
A. An Gen. 3.6 overvaluing, of what's in the poſſeſſion of others.
Q. May not the things of others be more excellent, then thoſe poſseſt by us?
A. Yes 1 Cor, 12, 16. in themſelvs, but not to us.
Q. VVhy ſo?
A. Becauſe 1 Cor. 12, 11. our heavenly Father thinks it otherwiſe.
Q. Is that best for us which is of GODS providing?
A. Yes Mat. 6.30..

Q. VVhat's the fruit of all this?
Sect. 32
A. Reſt Mat, 11, 28..
Q. How mean you?
A. Where it is in all the ibid, extent of it.
Q. VVhere is that?
A. In Rom. 10. Chriſt.
Q. How ſo?
A. He Heb. 10.10. did the wil of GOD.
Q. As how?
A. He kept the law.
Q. What's the end of ſuch keeping of it?
A. Reſt Mat. 19 17. and peace.
Q. To whom?
A. To them that beleeve.
Q. Why was the law given?
A. To reveal ſin.
Q. And why too?
A. To ſet out and magnifie the grace of GOD.
Q. Is not the law then the rule of life?
A. None have life Mat, 19.17., but in the fulfilling of it.
Q. Who then can have life?
A. Thoſe to Mat. 13.11. whom its given.
Q. Who are they?
A. Thoſe to whom Rom. 5, 15. Chriſt is given.
Q. Who are they?
A. Such Eph. 1, 4. as were choſen in him.
Q. When?
A. Before ibid. the world was.
Q. How did they appear to GOD in him?
A. Very Iſa. 52, 1. glorious.
Q. How doth GOD bring them to that glory?
A. He made 1 Cor. 3, 21, 22. the world for them.
Q. How mean you?
A. That Rom. 8, 19. he might bring them forth in it.
A. To ſet Eph. 1.6. forth his praiſe.
Q. Declare your meaning?
A. To ſet Rom, 9.23. forth his his goodneſs.
Q. What too?
A. His Eph. 3.10. wiſdome.
Q. What elſe?
A. His Rom, 3.26. righteouſneſſe.
Q. Is the world then for their ſake?
A. Yes Col. 1.16 in Chriſt.

Q. How doth GOD make his wiſdome, goodneſſe, and righteouſneſse
to appear unto them?
A. Two ways.
Q. Name the first?
A. By Gen. 1.26. Creation.
Q. Name the ſecond?
A. By Eph. 2.10 Redemption.
Q. How did GOD make out himſelfe in the Creation?
A. 1 Cor, 15, 45. Weakly.
Q. How mean you?
A. verſe 46. Comparatively.
Q. In compariſon of what?
A. Of his making himſelfe 2 Cor, 4, 6. out in the Goſpel.
Q. How doth that appear?
A. Sathan deceived Adam through his belying God in that Gen. 3, 5 appearance.
Q. How mean you?
A. He made him beleeve that ibid. which was not.
Q. What was that?
A. A Joh. 8.44 lye.
Q. Did all men then (through Sathan) trust in a lye?
A. Rom. 3, 12. Yes.
Q. How doth that appear?

A. They Gen. 3. found death & ruine, in that wherein they thought to have had encreaſe of life
and glory.
Q. Why did GOD ſuffer his to be thus deceived?
A. For a twofold cauſe.
Q. Name the first?
A. That he might make Rom. 9.11. way for the execution of his eternall purpoſe.
Q. What was that?
A. A diſtinction betwixt the ſons of GOD and the ſons Rom. 8.19. of men.
Q. When did he that?
A. When they Rom. 9.11. were all equally involv'd in ſin and miſery.

Q. Why was not the purpoſe
of GOD declared till then?
A. For two cauſes.
Q. Tell the firſt?
A. That the grace Rom. 5, 21. of GOD, among the Sons of GOD, might be much more abundantly magnified.
Q. How doth that conduce to this?
A. In that they were ſhut up in the Rom. 3, 9. ſame pit of death and condemnation with all the world.
Q. What's the ſecond cauſe?
A. That Rom. 3, 19. every mouth might be ſtopped.
Q. How?
A. Every v. ibid. one by nature chooſeth death, rather then life.
Q. How mean you?
A. They (as Gen. 3. Adam) pleaſe themſelves to their own ruine.
Q. Why elſe did GOD ſuffer his in Adam to be thus deceived?
A. Becauſe Heb. 11 he intended for them a more glorious reſurrection.
Q. What is the meaſure of that glory?
A. The holy Mar, 19, 17. Commandment.
Q. How mean you?
A. The sbid, fulfilling of it.
Q. Where is that?
A. Alo • e in Chriſt.
Q. Sect. 33 Can no man then keep the law?
A. Not Rom, 5, 6 of himſelf.
Q. What's the life of ſuch a man?
A. Luke 10 30. Miſerable.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe he Rom, 3, 23. comes ſhort of the glory of GOD.
Q. Is there no help for man in this condition?
A. He Ezek, 16 4. cannot help himſelf.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe Rom, 5, 6 he is without ſtrength.

Q. Is there any takes
pity on him?
A. None Ezek, 16 6, but GOD.
Q. Doth he pity man in this condition?
A. Yes ibid,.
Q. How doth it appear?
A. He hath Pſal. layne help upon one that is mighty.
Q. Mighty to what?
A. To Rom. 1, 16 ſave.
Q. Who is that?
A. Jeſus Iſa. 53, 1 Chriſt.

div.head: Part. II.
div.p:
Q. 2 Part.
WHat then is the third way of knowing GOD?
Sect. 1
A. By the Rom, 1.16 Goſpel.
Q. What is the Goſpel?
A. The Mat. 1, 1, 23. tydings of the myſtery of GOD in the fleſh.
Q. VVhat tydings?
A. Glad Rom. 10.15. tydings.
Q. Of what?
A. A Levit, 25 10, Releaſe.
Q. From what?
A. From Iſa. 61.1 priſon.
Q. What Priſon?
A. Mat, 1, 21 Sin.
Q. What too?
A. Hoſea 13 14. Death.
Q. And what?
A. 1 Theſ. 1, 10. Wrath.
Q. What beſides?
A. The Gal. 4, 5 Law.
Q. What elſe?
A. The Heb. 2.14 1 Cor, 15, 55. Devil and Hell.
Q. And what too?
A. The Gal, 1, 4. World.
Q. Was man fettered in all theſe chains?
A. Iſa. 24, 22. Yes.
Q. Who then was able to releaſe him?
A. None 1 Joh. 4 10 but GOD.

Q. How mean you?
Sect. 2
A. GOD Ioh. 3.16 ſent his Son.
Q. Who was he?
A. The Ioh, 1, 1 14, Word.
Q. What was that Word?
A. GOD. ibid.
Q. How mean you?
A. The Mic, 5, 2 goings In principio erat verbum. forth of GOD.
Q. What were they?
A. From ibid, in the margin. of old, from the days of eternity.
Q. VVas this the Son of GOD?
A. Ioh, 1, 14 Yes.
Q. VVhere is he?
A. In the Joh, 1, 18 boſome of the Father.
Q. How did he releaſe us?
A. He Ioh. 1, 14 was made fleſh.

Q. How mean you?
Sect. 3
A. He Gal. 4.4. was made of a woman.
Q. As how?
A. He Mat. 1.18 was born of Mary.
Q. What was ſhe?
A. A Mat. 1.23 Virgin.
Q. How then could ſhe have a ſon?
A. There Iſa. 7.13 14. is nothing too hard for GOD.
Q. How then came it to paſse?
A. That Luk. 1, 28. &c. the Angel told Mary.
Q. What ſaid the Angel to Mary?
A. The Luk. 1.35 Holy Ghoſt ſhall come upon thee; And the power of the higheſt ſhall overſhadow thee.
Q. VVhat was the Name given him at his birth?
A. Luk. 1.31 JESUS.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe Mat 1.21 he was to ſave his people from their ſins.

p.hi: Q. What other name had he given him then?

div.p: A. Mat. 1, 23. Emmanuel.
Q. What is that?
A. GOD with us.
Q. How did this conduce to our releaſement out of Priſon?

A.
Sect. 4 GOD Phil. 2.6 7, 8. himſelfe was now as it were impriſon'd with us.
Q. How doth that appear?
A. He Gal. 4, 4 was made under the law.
Q. And what too?
A. He 2 Cor, 5.21. was made ſin.
Q. What elſe?
A. A Gal. 3.13 curſe.
Q. What beſides?
A. A Iſai 53.3 ſcorn.
Q. Was he under wrath?
A. Yes Mat. 26, 39. in a ſort.
Q. Did Death ceaſe upon him?
A. Phil. 2, 8 Yes.
Q. And who too?
A. Luke 22 53. Sathan.
Q. VVhat elſe?
A. The Mat, 16 18. very gates of Hell.
Q. How did he behave himſelf in this condition?
A. He Iſa, 50, 7 truſted in God.
Q. VVhat, GOD in GOD?
A. The Ioh. 20 17, Son in the fleſh truſted in the Father.
Q. How ſhewed hee that?
A. He ſet his Iſa, 50, 7 face like a flint.
Q. What to do?
A. To Iſa, 50, 7 6. ſuffer.
Q. From whom?
A. From Mat. 26, 39. GOD.
Q. And who too?
A. The Joh. 15.18. World.
Q. And who elſe?
A. Luke 22 53. Sathan.
Q. How long did his ſufferings last?

A. Till Mat. 27, he gave up
the Ghost.
Q. Sect. 5 Who was crucified hereby?
A. The Rom. 6.6 old Man.
Q. What was this old man?
A. The Gal. 2.20. ſinful man.
Q. Is this ſinful man ceaſed?
A. Yes Col. 1.21, 22. in Chriſt.
Q. How ſo?
A. He was left Col. 2.13, 14. Eph. 2.15. nail'd upon the Croſſe.
Q. How could this be?
A. He had there his Gal. 3.13 deſerved ruine.
Q. How ſo?
A. He Rom. 8.1 was arraigned in Chriſt.
Q. And what too?

A. Condemned Phil. 2.8 in
See John Valdeſso Conſiderat. 11. a book happily brought into our Engliſh Coaſts. Chriſt.
Q. And what too?
A. He Rom. 6.6 was deſtroyed in Chriſt.
Q. What item did Chriſt give of this?
A. The Ioh. 19.30 words hee ſpake before he gave up the Ghoſt.
Q. What were they?
A. It Ibid. is finiſhed.
Q. What did follow hereupon?
A. Sect. 6 The Cor. 15.4 Reſurrection.
Q. What was the Reſurrection?
A. A Act. 2.24 looſing of the pains of Death.
Q. What mean you?
A. A Iſa. 45.1. breaking Cyrus was a type of Chriſt. open of the Priſondoors.
Q. The doors of what Priſon?
A. Of Sin, of Death; of Wrath; of Hell Rev. 1.18; of the Grave.
Q. Of what too?
A. The Gal. 4.5. Law.

p.hi: Q. Was the Law a Priſon?

div.p: A. It Act. 15 24. kept men in bondage.
Q. How ſo?
A. It 1 Cor. 15, 56. was the ſtrength of Sin.

A. By it Rom. 5.20. ſin became
exceeding ſinfull.
Q. As how?
A. It appeared infinitely Rom. 4.15 meritorious of wrath.
Q. Sect. 7 Were we involv'd in Christ's death?
A. Rom. 6.8 Yes.
Q. Had we a ſhare too in his reſurrection or releaſe?
A. Eph. 2.5 Yes.
Q. How?
A. All 1 Cor. 1.30. that he is, he is to us.
Q. How mean you?
A. He Col. 2, 19 is the head of the body.
Q. What then?
A. He Iſa. 53.6 was our repreſentative.
Q. How was Christ our repreſentative?
A. He Heb. 5.1. tranſacted all our affairs.
Q. With whom?
A. With ibid, GOD.
Q. Sect. 8 What did he undertake to GOD for us?
A. He Heb 9.25 offer'd himſelf to dye for us.
Q. Did GOD accept of his offering?
A. He Mat. 3.7 was exceedingly well pleaſed with him in all this.
Q. What did he undertake to accompliſh by his death?

A. To bring Heb. 2.10 many
ſons to glory.
Q. Did he accompliſh his deſign?
A. Col. 1.22 Yes.
Q. In what plight doth he preſent them to his Father?
A. ibid, Perfect.
Q. How mean you?
A. Holy, unblameable, and unreprovable in his ſight.
Q. Sect. 9 How was he our repreſentative too?
A. In Joh. 1.16 that whatſoever he received from the Father, he received it in our behalfe.
Q. What had we from the Father?
A. His Col. 1.19 fulneſſe.
Q. And what too?
A. His Ioh. 17 22. glory.
Q. What elſe?
A. His 2 Cor. 5, 21. Righteouſnes
Q. Had he all this for us?
A. Yes, and Eph. 3.8 much more then can be expreſt.
Q. What is he then to us?
A. He is GOD Tit. 2.13 to us.
Q. How elſe expreſſed?
A. He Mat. 1.23. is God with us.
Q. How is he made out unto us?
As 1 Cor. 1, 30. our wiſdom.
Q. And how too?
A. As 1 Cor. 1, 30. our Righteouſneſſe.
Q. And how elſe?
A. As ibid. our Sanctification and Redemption.
Q. Sect. 10 Whoſe repreſentative too was he?
A. He Heb. 12, 25. was GODS Agent here on earth.
Q. What did he here in the behalf of GOD?
A. He did Luk. 2.49 negotiate all his affairs here.
Q. What affairs?
A. Thoſe Mat. 4.23. that concerned his Church and Kingdom.
Q. Name one of them?
A. He Ioh. 17, 6. made out his Fathers Name.
Q. Name another?
A. Being Rom, 3, 17. all out of the way, he ſet us Ioh. 10.9 in the way.
Q. Name a third?
A. He 1 Io. 3.8 ſleighted the works of the devil.
Q. What did he then?
A. He Ioh. 6.62 went where he was before.
Q. Hath he then left his Church.
A. Yes Ioh. 16, 5 in reſpect of that Miniſtration.

Q. How mean you?
Sect. 11
A. His 1 Tim. 3 16. appearing for us (as then) in the fleſh.

Q. How is he with
his Church?
A. As Ioh, 14, 16, 18 A Comforter.
Q. How mean you?
A. He Ioh. 14, 23. is preſent in the Spirit.
Q. How long will he thus abide with his Church.
A. For Mat, 28, 20. evermore.

Q. What doth the Comforter?
Sect. 12
A. Bring Ioh, 14, 26. all things into our Remembrance.
Q. What things?
A. The Ibid. things concerning Chriſt.
A. Shew Ioh, 16, 13, us things to come.
Q. What too?
A. Convince Ioh, 16, 8 the world of ſin, of righteouſneſſe, and judgment.
A. Seal Eph 4.30 us unto the day of Redemption.
Q. What Redemption?
A. The Rom, 6, 23. Redemption of our bodies.

Q. How will that be?
Sect. 13
A. By his Rom, 8, 11. Spirit that dwelleth in us.
Q. When will that be?
A. When Luk, 21.28. Chriſt appears.
Q. How mean you?
A. In Mat, 16, 27. his Fathers glory.

Q. What will then
come to paſse?
A. He 2 Theſ. 1, 10. will be glorified in his Saints, and admired in al them that do beleeve.
Q. And what too?
A. They that are not in him, will fly 1 Ioh, 3, 17. comp. with Rev, 6, 15, 16. from him.
Q. What will that be?
A. Their Iude 15, deſtruction.
Q. What destruction?

A.
Sect. 14 A 2 Theſ. 1, 9, Deſtruction from his preſence.
Q. And what too?
A. From ibid, the glory of his power.
Q. What demonstration may be given of this?
A. Mens Iſa. 33.14 flying from him now.
Q. How mean you?
A. From Mat. 3, 11, 12. his Baptiſm.

Q. What baptiſm?
Sect. 15
A. The Mat. 3, 11. baptiſm of fire.
Q. Is that ſo terrible?
A. verſe 12 Yes.
Q. How ſo?
A. It Ibid. conſumes the ſinner root and branch.
Q. How mean you?
A. It takes 1 Cor, 1 29, away his glory.
Q. What is his glory?
A. His Phil. 3.19. ſin in the imaginary ſweeteneſſe of it.
Q. And what too?
A. His Dan. 10.8 Righteouſneſſe.
Q. And what?
A. His 1 Cor. 1.20. wiſdom.
Q. What elſe?
A. His Rev. 1.17. ſtrength.
Q. What's the plight of thoſe, that are ſo deſpoiled?
A. They Acts 9.9 are left in darkneſſe.
Q. What all?
A. The Eph. 5.8. night of ſome, is turned into day.
Q. As how?
A. The 2 Pet. 1.19. day-ſtarre from on high, ariſeth in their hearts.
A. They Eph. 5.8 become light in the Lord.

p.hi: Q. What's the condition of thoſe are not thus viſited?

div.p: A. They Pſa. 49.14 are in hel.
Q. What, here?
A. Yes Mat 24.8 in the ſuburbs of it.
Q. Sect. 16 How wil it be with both at the laſt day?
A. They Mat. 25, 31, to the end. wil be perfect light, and perfect darkneſſe; perfect life, and perfect death; perfect joy & perfect woe: and therefore perfectly ſeparated one from another.
Q. How ſo?
A. The ibid. one ſhall have all that may make them happy; the other ſhall ſee nothing, but what ſhall make them miſerable.
Q. Sect. 17 Which is the moſt excellent way of knowing GOD?
A. Our 1 Cor. 12.31. knowing him in the Goſpel.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe Heb. 11.1 in that light only we ſee him as he was before, and ſince the fall, manifeſted unto men.
Q. How is the Goſpel then to be eſteem'd?
A. As Mat. 13.44. great riches.
Q. How mean you?
A. The Eph. 3.8 bleſsings of it cannot be expreſt.
Q. Sect. 18 VVhat means is inſtituted for the making of it out?
A. The 2 Cor. 3, 8. Miniſtery of the ſpirit.
Q. VVho is ſufficient for it?
A. No 2 Cor. 2, 16. man of himſelf.
Q. VVho then gives ſufficiency?
A. The 2 Cor. 3, 5. ſufficiency is of GOD only.

Q. Sect. 19 May it be carryed on without that which we commonly call Humane
Learning?
A. Act. 4.13 Yes.
Q. How ſo?
A. By the inward Rev. 10.9, 10, 11. 2 Cor. 3.6. 1 Joh. 2 27 mighty and ſecret teaching of the Holy Spirit.
Q. VVho were ſo taught?
A. The Act. 1, 8. Apoſtles.
A. Chriſt Luk. 4.18 himſelf.
Q. As how?
A. As ibid. man.
Q. Are any ſo taught at this day?
A. There 1 Joh. 2.20. is no true teaching but by the ſame anointing.

Q. VVhat is that
anointing?
A. The 1 Ioh. 2.27. Spirit.
Q. VVhat is the Spirit to ſuch?
Q. Its Ioh, 7.38 in them a well of living water, ſpringing up unto everlaſting life.
Q. Are they the true preachers?
A. Sect. 20 They Acts 1, 4 Ier, 23, 21 that are not ſuch, run before they are ſent.
A. They have Ier, 23, 16 ſeen nothing.
A. They 1 Cor, 11, 23 have received nothing.
Q. What then?
A. They Eph. 3, 5. can reveal nothing.
Q. What are ſuch then?
A. Blind Mat. 23, 16. guides.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe ibid, they undertake to lead others, the way themſelvs know not.
Q. Is there no uſe of the learning men cal humane?

A.
Sect. 21 There 1 Cor, 3.20. is uſe of all things.
Q. VVhat's the ordinary abuſe of learning?
A. It 1 Cor. 8.1 puffs men up.
Q. How?

A. It 1 Cor. 8.2 makes men think they know many
things, when they know nothing at all, as they ſhould know.
Q. What follows hereupon?
A. Contempt 3 Joh. 9. of the brethren.
Q. When is there a right uſe of ſuch learning?
A. When Iſa. 60.14 it is laid at Chriſts feet.
Q. How mean you?
A. When Iſa. 60.13 it is made to ſerve him.
Q. Sect. 22 How is the Myſtery of GOD, in the knowledg of it increaſed, among them that beleeve?
A. Divers Eph. 3.10 ways.
Q. Tell the first?
A. They Act. 2.42 continue in the Apoſtles doctrine.
Q. VVhat doctrine?
A. The Tit. 2.10. doctrine they taught.
Q. VVhat doctrine did they teach?
A. The Ibid. doctrine of GOD and our Saviour JESUS.
Q. Is that doctrine known among men at this day?
A. Yes Rev. 21, 14..
Q. How ſo?
A. By the Eph. 2.20. writings of the Old and New Teſtament.

Q. How come you to
understand them?
A. By the ſame 2 Pet. 1.20. Spirit that compos'd them.
Q. Is the Spirit that was in the Apoſtles and Prophets, as yet in the Church?
A. 1 Pet. 3, 19. Rev. 19, 10. Acts 2.18. Yes.
Q. How?
A. In a 1 Cor. 12 11. meaſure.
Q. Sect. 23 How elſe is the knowledge of Chriſt increaſed among them that beleeve?
A. By Acts 2.42. continuing in the Apoſtles fellowſhip.
Q. The Apoſtles Iob. 21.19. they are dead.
A. Yes Iob 10.21, 22. to men.
Q. Are they then alive?
A. Yes Rom. 6.11. to GOD.
Q. Are we then come unto them?
Q. How ſo?
A. To ibid. the Spirits of juſt men made perfect.
Q. And how?
A. To ibid. the General Aſſembly and Church of the firſt born, whoſe Names are enrol'd in Heaven.
Q. Can that be?

A. We ſit with Abraham, Iſaac, and Jacob in the Kingdome
of Heaven.
Q. Can this be demonstrated?
A. Yes.
Q. How?
A. The Jam. 2.5. Kingdome of GOD is but one.
Q. What then?
A. They Luke 12 32. are all the children of that Kingdome.
Q. What Kingdome?
A. The Mat. 3.2 Kingdome of Heaven.
Q. Where is this Kingdome?
A. Its Luke 17 21. in them that beleeve.
Q. How mean you?
A. Its Eph. 1.14. Phil. 3.20. begun on earth.
Q. Give another demonſtration of it?
A. They 1 Cor. 6.17. 1 Cor 12, 13. are all one Spirit.
Q. Give a third?
A. They are Eph. 3.15. of the ſame Family.
Q. How do they differ?
A. Some 2 Cor. 5.6. are in the bodys and ſome are out of the body, with the LORD.
Q. What is the Communion of them in the body?
A. It is Act. 2.46 Local.
Q. How mean you?
A. They Ibid, come together in the ſame place.
Q. How?
A. As they Gal. 6.10 Heb. 10.25 have opportunity.
Q. How elſe is their Communion?
A. Mal. 3.16 Vocal.
Q. What's your meaning?
A. They 1 Pet. 4.11. ſpeak the words of life, one to another.
Q. To what end?
A. To edifie Iude 20. themſelves, in their holy faith.
Q. How come they together?
A. Of Iſa. 60.5. a ready mind.
Q. How do they keepe together?
A. They Col. 2.2. are kept together by the power of God.

p.hi: Q. Do they not fall aſunder one from another?

div.p: A. Never Rom. 8.38, 39. wholy.
A. Becauſe Eph. 1.23 they are all of one body.
A. The ibid, LORDS Body.

p.hi: Q. What is the Lords Body?

div.p: A. The ibid, Church.
Q. VVhat is the Church?
A. The ib. fulneſſe of Chriſt.
Q. Where is the Church?
A. In Eph. 3.15 Heaven and Earth.
Q. Sect. 24 What is the third way the Saints take for their increaſe in the knowledge of Christ?
A. Breaking Acts 2. of bread.
Q. To what end?
A. To 1 Cor. 11, 26. ſhew forth the Lords death till he come.
Q. How doth the breaking of bread, ſhew forth the Lords death?
A. By Luk. 22, 19. ſhewing the end of it.

Q. What was the end
of Chriſts death?
A. To Phil. 3, 3 take away our rejoycing in the fleſh.

p.hi: Q. How doth Christs death, take away our rejoycing in the fleſh?

div.p: A. Chriſt 1 Pet. 4.1 ſuffered for us in the fleſh.
Q. What then?
A. That ib, v. 2. we no longer, ſhould live the reſt of our time to the luſts of men.
Q. How mean you?
A. After ibid. the will of man.
Q. How then?
A. To ibid. the will of GOD.
Q. What then was Chriſts death?
A. The Io, 3, 5 Death of ſinne.
Q. And what too?
A. All 2 Tim. 1 9. that which, to the hurt of man, came in with ſin.
Q. Is this ſeen in the Supper?
A. Yes Gal. 3, 1..
Q. How?
A. By Ioh, 6, 40 faith.
Q. What elſe is this a figure of?
A. The 1 Cor, 10, 16, 17. Saints fellowſhip.
Q. In what?
A. In ibid, the Lord Jeſus.
Q. How?
A. They ib. v. 17. being many, are one bread.
Q. What doth it figure out beſides?
A. Our Joh. 6.48 heavenly life.
Q. How mean you?
A. Its ibid. the food of life.
Q. How?
A. To Ioh. 6.35 faith it preſents Chriſt.
Q. Sect. 25 Who may come to the Supper?
A. All Rev. 22, 17. that have a will to come.
Q. May that be?

A. Chriſt Iſa. 25.6. cals ſinners to himſelf in this,
as well as in the reſt of the Miniſtrations; and the Iſa. 60.11 gate of heaven is to ſtand open in this, as well as in any other ordinance of GOD.
Q. Are we not to put a difference, between the precious and the vile?
A. The Mat. 22, 11. Lord himſelf doth that.
Q. How mean you?
A. At his Mat. 24, 39. coming.
Q. What coming do you mean?
A. His Mal. 3.2 coming in this, and the reſt of the Miniſtrations.
Q. What is this his coming?
A. Mal. 3, 2 Terrible.
A. 'Tis ibid. as refiners fire, and as fullers ſope.
Q. What do the ſinners and hypocrites ſay of it?
A. Who Iſa. 33, 44. among us ſhal dwel with devouring fire.
Q. What do ſuch then?
A. Go Amos 4.4 to the Miniſtrations where Chriſt is not.
Q. What are ſuch?
A. Lu. 15.16 Husks for ſwine.
Q. What are they advantaged by them?

A. They are Ezek. 34 16. fatned and confirmed by them, in their ſpiritual, and
open pride, and prophaneſſe.
Q. What follows hereupon?
A. A Ezek. 34, 21. ſcorning of, and a trampling upon the brethren.
Q. What are ſuch a people?
A. A Rev. 17.4 carnal Church.
A. A Rev. 17.6 Church Malignant.
Q. May not an unbeleever poſsiblycome to this Miniſtration diſpenſd in Chriſts name?
A. Poſſibly Acts 5.12, 13, 14., but not uſually.
Q. Why ſo?
A. It hath the Acts 2.42, 43, 44. ſame operation with the word.
Q. What word?
A. The word that Heb 4.12 is quick and powerful.
Q. What then?
A. He Act. 2.43 will have no heart to either long.
Q. If he come, doth he pollute the Supper?
A. The Mat. 7.6. 1 Cor. 11.20. Supper cannot be polluted.
Q. Why ſo?
A. The Supper is indeed the Lord himſelf, whom the unbeleever cannot receive.
Q. Who is polluted then?
A. He Tit. 1.15 that hath not faith.
Q. Why ſo?
A. There is ibid, nothing pure to him.
Q. Are ſuch to be kept from the Supper?
A. They Eph. 2: 12. are abſent, though they ſeem preſent.
Q. May none be kept from it?
A. Not 2 Cor. 10.4. by external force.
Q. By what then?
A. The Gen. 3.24. two-edged ſword & rod of Chriſts mouth.

A. The Iſa. 26.1 Church hath
no other fence.
Q. Sect. 26 Is not the Magiſtrate the Churches fence?
A. Yes Tim. 2.1, 2. as he is the fence of other men.
Q. How mean you?
A. From Rom. 13 3, 4. outward wrong and violence.
Q. What is the Magistrate in this?
A. A Iſa. 49.23 Nurſing father.
Q. How ſo?
A. Herein ibid. he bowes to Chriſts ſcepter.
Q. How mean you?
A. He Phil. 2.9 10, 11. confeſſerh Chriſts ſoveraignty.
Q. Over whom?
A. The Heb. 12 9 ſpirits of men
Q. May not the Magistrate interpoſe with his power, in matters purely appertaining to GOD?
A. He hath Rev. 17.2 hitherto been abuſed, by ſuch ſuggeſtions.
Q. As how?
A. He hath been Rev. 13.15. engaged againſt GOD and his truth.
Q. How doth that appear?
A. There Rev. 14.20. are tokens of it, all Chriſtendome over.
Q. What are they?
A. Perſecution Rev. 16, 13, 14., war, and confuſion.
Q. What do theſe?
A. Break Rev. 2.27. the Nations like a potters veſſel.

p.hi: Q. Is not this rod in Chriſts hand?

div.p: A. Pſa. 2.9 Yes.
Q. What doth hee aime at, in weilding of it?
A. The Rev. 19, 2.6. regaining of his ſoveraignty.
Q. Over whom?
A. The Rev. 11.15. Nations.
Q. In what things?
A. In Rev. 19.6 things appertaining to himſelf.
Q. Do not the Nations then acknowledge his King-ſhippe over them?
A. They Rev. 13.3 all welnigh bow down, to ſome other Lord.
Q. What other Lord?
A. Rev. 12, 9, 13, 14. Sathan.
Q. How comes that to paſse?
A. By the Rev. 19.20. inſinuations of the falſe prophet.
Q. What is that falſe prophet?
A. The ibid, Pope, and the Popiſh Clergy.
Q. At what do they aime?
A. Their Phil. 3.19 owne belly.
Q. How do they attain that which they aim at?
A. They Rev. 13.17. get themſelves confirmed by a law.
Q. What do they then?
A. Keep Rev. 9, 1, 2. the people in ignorance.
A. Live Iſa. 56.11, 12. in luxury.
Q. Sectl. 27 What then's the wiſdome of the Magistrate?
A. To Phil. 3.2 beware of ſuch.
Q. What too?
A. Not to lean Iſa. 11, 13, 14. to the right hand, or to the left.
Q. What mean you?

A. Not to 2 Chr. 10 20. ſtrengthen one Sect of men,
againſt another.
Q. How mean you?
A. Among Mat. 20.26. Chriſtians.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Leaſt they Rev, 17, 13. run upon the ſame rock, as do the Papiſts.
Q. What do they?
A. Urge Rev, 13.3 Popery, but neglect Chriſtianity.
Q. May the like be found among Proteſtants?
A. 'Twas ſo in England.
Q. When?
A. Before this Parliament began.
Q. As how?
A. Conformity Gal. 6.12 had welnigh thruſt out Chriſtianity.
Q. Declare your meaning?
A. 'Twas Col. 3.11 not enough to be a Chriſtian.
Q. Is this remedyed?
A. Scarce any where in the world.
Q. Can that be?
A. Scarce any man, in any Nation, is embraced meerly, as 1 Pet. 4.16. a Chriſtian.
Q. How then.
A. As a Chriſtian, that is of Mat. 5.46, 47. ſuch or ſuch an opinion.
Q. What do you judge of this?
A. Its Gal. 6.14, 15, 16. the ſhame of Chriſtendom.
Q. And what too?
A. The Iſa. 60.12 ruine of the Nations, profeſſing it.
Q. When will this be remedyed among them?
A. When Iſa. 11.6. Chriſt is acknowledged by them.
Q. VVhy will nothing but the knowledge of Chriſt alone, heal the Nations?
A. Becauſe 1 Cor. 1 30. he alone is al for us to GOD, and all in us, to our ſelves, and others.
Q. VVhat of that?
A. When he is all, and we (in our own account) nothing at all Iſa, 11, 9; there wil be an end of all ſtrife.
Q. Sect. 28 VVhat's the last way the Saints have to grow in Chriſt?
A. They Act 2, 42 Continue in prayer.
Q. VVhat is prayer?
A. The Rom. 8.26. ſpirit in us, makes interceſſion for us.
Q. How?
A. According ver. 27. to the will of GOD.
Q. May we not aske then whatever comes in our heads?
A. By Eccleſ. 5 2, 3, no means.
Q. May we ſpeak our own words, in prayer?
A. verſe 1. Neither.
A. Must we ask in faith?
A. Jam, 1, 6 Yes.
Q. VVhat is faith?
A. A beleeving what 2 Cor, 4 13. GOD ſays.
Q. Why muſt we aske in faith?
A. He that beleeves nothing, can receive nothing, in Jam. 1.7. prayer.
Q. VVhy?
A. Ibid, Becauſe he asks a miſſe.
Q. How come you then to GOD in prayer?
A. By Joh. 14.6 him.
Q. How mean you?
A. By ibid, Chriſt.
Q. How ſo?
A. We have 1 Cor. 2.16. his mind.
Q. How?
A. His Rom. 8.9 Spirit.
Q. Sect. 29 What's the Churches pale?
A. Rev. 21.22. Chriſt.
Q. Why ſo?
A. None Joh. 10.9. can be in the Church that come not in by him.
Q. Are not men received into the Church by baptiſm?
A. Heb 12.28. No.

Q. Sect. 30 VVhat's the uſe
then of baptiſm?
A. Its a Miniſtration, ſerving to the making 1 Pet. 3, 21. out of Chriſt to men.
Q. May infants be baptized?
A. Yes, if Rom. 14 14. men be ſo perſwaded.
Q. How mean you?
A. If they Rom. 14 22. have faith.
Q. May an infant be baptized in faith?
A. Yes Ibid. doubtleſſe.
A. All our things are to be done Rom. 14 23. in faith.
Q. Is there a rule for ſuch baptiſm?
A. Not expreſt.
Q. VVhat's the rule of things not expreſt?
A. I 1 Cor. 10.23. can do al things, but wil not be brought under the power of any.
Q. VVhat's the ordinary uſe of Infant-baptiſme?
A. Its 1 Cor. 3, 1, 3. for the moſt part Carnal.
Q. How ſo?
A. Its Mat. 28, 19. Carnally adminiſtred.
Q. And why too?
A. To a Iſa. 1.12 Carnall end.
Q. VVhat's the fruit of both?

A. Strife 1 Cor. 3.3. and Contention
about it.
Q. Have the infants of ſome parents more right to baptiſme then others?
A. Men Mat. 15. 2. Ron 3 9. have received that but by tradition.
Q. Do not moſt parents baptiſe their children, under ſuch a Notion?
A. Yes.
Q. VVhy ſo?
A. Becauſe Mar. 7.7 they are ſo inſtructed.
Q. By whom?
A. Their ibid. teachers.
Q. Under what Notion, do you judge it meet to baptiſe?
A. As a 1 Pet. 3, 21. means to make out the doctrine & faith I have received.
A. To the Mat. 5.16 World.
Q. And whom too?
A. The 1 Cor. 14 12. Church.
Q. What doctrine is made out in baptiſm?
A. That Acts 4, 12. there is hope in Chriſt, and in none other.
A. Col 3.11 For young and old.
Q. Are you bound to this by a law?
A. By Rom. 13.10. the law of love.

Q. Sect. 31 May you uſe it or
not uſe it?
A. I have liberty 1 Cor, 10, 29. ſo to do.
Q. How?
A. If I 1 Cor, 8 8. uſe it, I am not the more accepted; and if I uſe it not I am not the leſſe accepted.
Q. Is it then in that reſpect, of the ſame nature with Circumciſion?
A. Yes Gal, 6.15, and all other outward things.
Q. May we ſuſpend the uſe of ſome outward things?
A. Gal, 2, 14 Yes.
Q. When?
A. When Gal. 2.14 Religion is placed in them.
Q. Doth not Religion conſiſt in them?
A. Rom. 14, 17. No.
Q. In what then?
A. In Ibid. righteouſneſs, peace, and joy in the holy Spirit.
Q. VVhat uſe then is there of outward things?
A. It ſerves Ioh. 3.12: onely to make out heavenly things.
Q. They are not then the heavenly things themſelves?
A. They Gal. 5.3 are Jew that know not Chriſt that ſo think.
Q. Are there any ſuch called Chriſtians?
A. The 1 Joh. 2, 18. moſt of the world are ſuch.
Q. How may they be deſcribed?
A. They Gal. 5.12 would make a fair ſhew in the fleſh.
Q. As how?
A. They'll v. ibid, conſtrain you to be circumciſed.
Q. How mean you?
A. Force ibid. you to outward things.
Q. How are the Saints •• ed out to outward things?
A. By 1 Pet, 4, 11, heavenly • hings.
Q. As how?
A. Firſt 1 Cor, 14, 30, they have them, and then ſhew them.
Q. How?
A. In 1 Pet, 4, 11, external Adminiſtrations.
Q. Are they ſlow in external obſervations?
A. They are 1 Cor, 15, 58, moſt active in them.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe 1 Pet, 1 23. they have the life and powe • of them.
Q. Why do's the worl • then deſpiſe them?
A. Becauſe Mat, 7, 28, 29. they d •• not perform them, as th • world.

Q. How do they performe
them?
A. As they are Col. 1.29 led out, of GOD.
Q. What is ſuch a performance?
A. Full of life, and power.
Q. How doth the world performe them?
A. With Gal. 1.10 reſpect to man.
A. Mat. 7.28, 29. Coldly.
Q. And how?
A. Without Iſa. 58.3 profit, without GOD.
A. To be ſaved ibid. by he doing of them.
Q. What are they?
A. Children Gal. 4.30, 31. of the bond woman.
Q. What then is the baptiſm of water?
A. A 1 Pet. 3.21. ſhadow.
Q. Why do men ſo ſtrive about it?
A. It ſhews Phil. 2.5 Mic, 6.6, 7 our unacquaintance with the ſubſtance.
Q. Of what is it a ſhadow?
A. A Col. 2 17 ſhadow of Chriſt.
Q. Is there a teaching by ſhadows in the New Teſtament?
A. Yes 1 Pet. 3.21..
Q. Why ſo?

A. Becauſe 1 Cor. 3 1. of
ſomes weakneſſe.
Q. What think you of the New Teſtament ſhadows?
A. They 1 Cor. 11 26. go out, as their ſubſtance comes in.
Q. Do you mean in practiſe?
A. No 1 Cor. 9.19, 20. but in eſteem.
Q. What eſteem have the moſt of them?
A. They Act. 15.1 embrace them as the ſubſtance.
Q. Sect. 32 What's the Chriſtian government?
A. Pſ. 110.3 Voluntary.
Q. How mean you?

A. Rebels Pſ. 68.18 are made
willing to ſubmit unto it.
Q. What? by the ſword of man?
A. No 2 Cor. 10.4., the arme and power of GOD.
Q. In whoſe hands, is it?
A. In Iſa. 9.6. Chriſts.
Q. What in his alone?
A. Yes Mat. 28.18..
Q. Is it Mat. 28.18. not deputed?
A. No Joh. 14.18.
Q. How is it then exerciſed?
A. By Mat. 28.20. his own preſence.
Q. In whom?

A. In Col. 1.27 all the ſubjects
of it.
Q. How is it put in execution?
A. According 2 Cor, 3 17. to the degree, of the Manifeſtation, of himſelf.
Q. Who are meet to go before others?
A. Thoſe Col. 1.18 in whom his preſence, doth moſt appear.
Q. How is his preſence manifeſted?
A. By 2 Cor. 10.4.5. the Word.
Q. What Word?
A. The Heb 4.12.13. quickning Word.
Q. How mean you?
A. The Word Joh. 6.63 made out in the Spirit.
Q. How is Chriſt thus manifested?
A. Eph. 3.10. Variouſly.
Q. Shew your meaning?
A. In 1 Cor. 12.6. ſome after one manner, and in ſome after another.
Q. Give an inſtance of it?
A. To 1 Cor. 12.8. one is given, by the Spirit, the word of wiſdome, to another the word of knowledge by the ſame Spirit.
Q. Sect. 33 What are ſuch in the Scripture phraſe?
A. Phil. 1.1 Biſhops, Eph. 4.11 Paſtors, Eph. 4.11 Teachers, Phil. 1.1 Elders, Phil. 1.1 Deacons.
Q. Are all ſuch, that are ſo call'd?
A. Moſt Mal. 1.11 are call'd that which they are not.
Q. What are ſuch then?
A. Joh. 10.1 Theeves and robbers.
Q. How elſe accounted?
A. Act. 20. Wolves in ſheeps cloathing.
Q. Are they that are ſuch (viz. Biſhops, Paſtors, Teachers, Elders, Deacons) ſo accounted?
A. Yes Rom. 10.15. of ſome.
Q. Who are they?
A. Such as can diſcern Chriſts, from a ſtrangers Ioh. 10.5.27. voyce.
Q. Are they not then accounted ſuch, of all?
A. They are 1 Cor. 4 10, 11, 12.13. to moſt, as the off-ſcouring of all things, untill this day.
Q. Doth that diſcourage them?
A. Nay, they Mat. 5.11.12. 2 Cor. 12.10. are encouraged thereby.
Q. How may that be?
A. They Rev. 10.10. have ate the book.
Q. What book?
A. The Rev. 5.8 9. Booke revealing GODS mind.
Q. What of that?
A. Its Rev. 10 10. bitter in their bellies.
Q. What doth that denote?
A. That ver. 11. 1 Tim. 3.2 ſuch alone are apt to teach.
Q. How mean you?
A. They Act. 4.20 cannot but teſtifie, the things they know.
Q. Is Chriſt then operative in the whole body?
A. He Col. 1.29 worketh in it mightily, but variouſly too.
Q. Sect. 34 Are none then to meddle in the Church, without ſuch an operation of GOD?
A. Not 1 Pet. 4.11. one.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Like 2 Sam. 6 6, 7. Uzzah, hee toucheth the Arke of God uncall'd.
Q. Will not the Call and appointment of men, or Miniſters, bear him out in it?
A. Not Jer. 23.21 at all.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe Gal. 1.1. they have no power.
Q. What is the utmoſt, the best of men or Ministers can do, in this caſe?
A. They Joh: 15.27. can onely bear witneſſe to the gift of GOD, by the ſame Spirit, by which it is given.
Q. Is it in their pleaſure, to give way to ſuch a Gift?
A. Sect. 35 Its Act. 7.51 their grievous ſin to oppoſe it.
Q. What ſin are many like to fall into, in this last age?
A. The Rev. 16.9 ſin againſt the holy Spirit.
Q. Why ſo?

A. The holy Act. 2.17 18.13. Spirit, being gloryouſly poured forth on them that beleeve, is in its operations,
mightily, and maliciouſly oppoſed, and blaſphemed, by ſome.
Q. Who are fartheſt off from this ſin?
A. They 2 Theſ. 2.10. that receive the truth, in love.
Q. How?
A. By Act. 18.26. whomſoever diſpenſed.
Q. What leads men to this ſin?
A. Selfe Lu 16.14 ends.
Q. When?
A. After Ioh. 9.41 ſome degrees of conviction.
Q. What's the end of ſuch men?

A. Their 2 Pet. 2.20. latter end
is worſe, then their beginning.
Q. How is this ſinne kept, from appearing to men?
A. It Ioh. 9.40 is hid, under cloak of profeſsion.
Q. A profeſsion! of what?
A. Of the Act. 6.13 law, and outward things.
Q. How is it expreſt?
A. In Ioh. 7.32 walking in a way of malice, againſt the moſt innocent.
Q. How is that malice expreſt?
A. In Iude 15. evill ſpeakings.
Q. In what too?
A. Caſting Mat. 5, 11. out their names as evill.
Q. And how too?
A. In Heb. 11.36. exquiſite torments.
Q. How?
A. As Ioh. 5.18 they have opportunity and power.

div.head: Part. III.
div.p:
Q. Sect. 1 3. Part.
HAving given the threefold way of knowing GOD by Christ; Shew the threefold way in which man is known to you by Chriſt?

A, I have already ſhewn the one, in, and
by the other.
Q. But ſhew it again, but distinctly and briefly; and firſt what was mans eſtate in innocency?
A. 'Twas Gen. 1.26. his beſt eſtate.
Q. What was he in this his best estate?
A. Pſ. 35.5. Vanity.
Q. How doth that appear?
A. In Gen. 3.19. the ſequel of it,
Q. How?
A. He 1 Pet. 1.24. withered like the graſſe of the field.

Q. Did God mind to
confirme him in this eſtate?
A. No Eph. 1.4.
Q. What then?
A. Ibid. He intended before the world was, to put him into a better.
Q. What eſtate could be better?
A. That Ro, 5.14. of which this firſt eſtate, Sect. 2 was but a figure.
Q. What was then Adams ſin?
A. His reflecting on, & embracing Gen. 3.5 of himſelf, who was but a figure, but neglecting Chriſt, the ſubſtance.
Q. Was Christ preacht in Paradiſe?
A. Yes.
Q. How doth that appeare?
A. He was figured out, there.
Q How?
A. In the tree of life, and man himſelf.
Q. What became of man, when he ſinned?
A. He Gen. 2.17. was like that brazen Serpent, to be beaten to peeces, or ground to powder.
Q. How is this done?
A. By Exod. 19.18. the Law.
Q. As how?

A. By Ibid, the terrors that
come along with the tranſgreſſion of it.
Q. What are they?
A. Innumerable Exod. 20 18..
Q. What's the condition then of man under the Law?
A. God Heb. 12.29. is a terror to him.
Q. Why?
A. Becauſe Exod. 20.19. he looks to be deſtroyed by him.
Q. Why?
A. For his Gen. 3.8 ſin.
Q. How great is his feare?
A. He fears Heb. 2.15. all the day long, and all his life long.

Q. Sect. 3 What's the onely
means to be freed from this feare?
A. Only the 1 Ioh. 4.18 knowledge of Chriſt.
Q. Why ſo?

A. Becauſe
Perditus Attritus Bernard on the word Bruiſed, Eſa. 53.5. hee was in a ſort deſtroyed for us, and we in a ſort deſtroyed in him.
Q. How could wee be deſtroyed in Chriſt?
A. We Ioh. 32.32. were comprehended in him.
Q. How?
A. In ibid. his death.
Q. As how?
A. In Rom. 4.3. Gods account.
Q. And how too?
A. In the Rom. 6.11 account of faith.
Q. How were we comprehended, in Christs death?
A. As 2 Cor. 5.21. ſinners.
Q. Are wee to reckon our ſelves dead?
A. Yes Col. 3 3. in Chriſt.
Q. To what?
A. To all ſinne Ro. 6.11..
Q. How mean you
A. To Col. 3.9. al that we are, in the firſt Adam.
Q. Did Christ only dye?
A. He 1 Cor. 15.3. roſe againe the third day.
Q. What doth that advantage us?
A. Eph. 2.6 Hee rayſed us with himſelfe.
Q. To what?
A. To Eph. 1.3: life & peace.
Q. To what end?
A. To live 1 Pet. 3.18. with God.
Q. How long?
For Rev. 1.18. evermore.
Q. Sect. 4 What then is the state of man, in Christ?
A. Moſt Eph. 1.18. happy. VVhy ſo?
A. Becauſe Philip. 3.10. he partakes of his death, and reſurrection.
Q. What hath he, by his death?
A. A 1 Joh. 3 5. freedome from ſinne.
A. All Eſa. 33.24. other evils.
Q. How?
A. By Heb. 33.24. Faith.
Q. VVhen will this appear?
A. When Col. 3.4 Chriſt appears.
Q. How will the Beleever then appear?
A. Perfect 1 Ioh. 4.17..
Q. As how?
A. As Chriſt Mat, 5, 48. is perfect.
Q. VVhat's the fruit you have of Chriſt riſing, and going to the Father?
A. Vnſpeakable. 2 Cor. 12, 4.
Q. Hint it from the Scripture, as you can?
A. He 1 Cor. 15.24. hath brought us to the Father.
Q. Where is then our home?
A. Heaven Phil. 3.20..
Q. Are we in Heaven?
Q. In Eph. 1.3 Chriſt.
Q. What doth this occaſion?
A. Ioy 1 Cor, 15.5. unſpeakable and full of glory.
Q. When?
A. In Phil. 1.21. life and death.
Q. VVhy?
A. Becauſe ibid. in either Chriſt is gain unto us.

p.hi: Q. VVhat's the fruit of this Ioy?

div.p: A. Becauſe 1 Cor. 15.3. of it we die daily.
A. To all Gal. 6.14. things here below
Q. Why ſo?
A. For Gal. 6.14. Chriſts ſake.
Q. Where is then your reſt?
A. In Heb. 4.9 Chriſt.
Q. What is the Converſation of ſuch a one, on earth?
A. Hee 1 Ioh. 5.3. walkes, in all the Commandements of God.
Q. How?
A. According Col. 1.29 to the gift, and power of God unto him.
Q. Is he a man of ſtrife?
A. He Rom. 12 21. overcomes evil with good.
Q. Is he profitable in his fellowſhip?
A. His Pro. 10.11. mouth is as a well of life.
Q. Doth he love in word only?
A. Hee 1 Ioh. 3.16, is willing to be ſpent for the brethren.
Q. Is he willing to communicate?
A. Yes 1 Tim, 6 18. freely, according to that which he hath.
Q. Will he do good to ſtrangers?

A. He
Gal. 6.10 doth good unto all, but eſpecially the houſhold of faith.
Q. Doth he glory in what he doth?
A. He 1 Cor. 1.31. gloryeth in the Lord only.
Q. Sect. 5 What's the concluſion of all?
A. f Beleeve and live.
Q. How ſ • ?
A. It Eph. 5.1 makes us, like God.
Q. Tel how?
A. It Heb. 11.1 makes preſent, things paſt, and to come.
Q. How mean you?
A. By 2 Cor. 4, it we live in eternity.
Q. Is not repentance needful?

A. Where Eph. 6.1 theſe
things are, there repentance, wil be.
Q. How mean you?
A. He Ioh. 6.45 that hath heard, and learned of the Father, will not be at the beck Iſa. 26.13, of any other Lord.
Q. What other Lord is there beſides?
A. Rom. 6.14. Sin.
Q. What is ſin?
A. A Gen. 3.13 deluſion.
A. It Gen. 3.6 makes a fair ſhew, but hath no ſubſtance.
Q. Declare your meaning?

A. 'Tis Iſa. 55.2 not the
thing it pretends to be, neither hath it that it pretends to give.
Q. What is that?
A. Lu. 15.16 Content.
Q. What is repentance then?
A. A Rom. 12.1. Heb. 8.10 Change, in the heart or mind.
Q. What change?
A. A Iam. 1.17 ſupernatural change.
Q. Why ſupernatural?
A. Becauſe Tit. 2.11 of the appearance, and communication, of that which appertains to another world.
Q. What doth ſuch an appearance, operate?
A. An 2 Cor. 7 11. abhorring of what is beneath it ſelf.
Q. Declare your meaning?
A. A Iob 42.6 loathing of whatever, ſtands incompetition, with it.
Q. What is that appearance, and communication?
A. The Gal. 6.15 New Creature.
Q. What of him?
A. He alone 1 Cor. 15.48: is heavenly.
Q How?
A. From 1 Cor. 15 47. Heaven.
Q. And how?
A. For Ioh. 3.13 Heaven.
Q. What is the New Creature?
A. The Pſa. 32.1, 2. bleſſed man.
Q. Who is hee?
A. The Iſa. 62.12 man reſtored.
Q. Unto! or into! what?
A. The 2 Cor. 3.18. image of God.
Q. What is that image?
A. Heb. 1.3 Chriſt.
Q. What's the conſequent of this appearance?

A,
Sect. 6 Tit. 3.5. Regeneration.
Q. What mean you?
A. The new birth, or the Ioh. 3.3. bringing forth of the Sons of God.
Q. From whence?
A. From Eph. 5.8 the womb of ſin, and darkneſs.
Q. How is your meaning?
A. From Eph. 2.12 their loſt, dead, and dark eſtate.
Q. Into what are they brought forth?
A. Into Col. 1.13 the Kingdom, of Gods dear Son.
Q. What have they there?
A. Gal. 4.26 Liberty.
Q. With whom?
A. With Col. 1.12 the Saints in light.
Q. Where is that?
In Gal 4.26 Rev. 21, 2 the New Hieruſalem.
Q. Is their dwelling there?
A. Rev. 3.12 Yes.
Q. How ſo?
A. They can live Ph. 3.20 no. where elſe.
Q. Whyſo?
A. Its Heb. 4, 3. their proper ſphere.
Q. Do they not then ſinne?
A. No Rev. 21.21. unclean thing, can be admitted there.
Q. Have they no ſinn then?
A. They are dead indeed, unto Rom. 6.12. ſin.
Q. Can that bee?
A. They Ibid, are to reckon themſelves, ſo.
Q. Doth not ſin appear in them?
A. Not 1 Ioh 3.9 as ſuch.
Q. Do they appear as ſuch?
A. They 1 Ioh 3.2 appear ſo, but in part.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe Iſa. 24.7 the vail is but in part, done away.
Q. How mean you?
A. As 1 Cor. 13 to them.
A. As Iam. 5.17 to others (in them).
Q. Is it not quite done away?
A. Yes 2 Cor. 3 16. in Chriſt.
Q. What is that vail?
A. The Heb. 10.20. fleſh.
Q. Is not ſin in it, as it is in us?
A. In it Rom. 7.18. there dwelleth no good thing.
Q. Do theſe new-born babes, delight in it?
A. They Rom. 7, 24. are burthened with it.
Q. What then is their delight?
A. To live Gal 5.25 in the Spirit.
Q. What is true of ſuch?
A. They have crucified the fleſh Gal 5.24, with its Gal 5.24 affections and luſts.
Q. If ſo, why do they yet hope?

A. Hope Heb. 6.13 anchors,
and ſtays them within the vaile.
Q. Where is that?
A. Where the Heb. 6.20 forerunner is gone before.
Q. Who is that? ibid.
A. Chriſt.
Q. Where is he?
A. In ibid. Heaven it ſelf.
Q. What doth hee there?
A. Appear Heb. 9.24 for us.
Q. What's the fruit of hope?
A. Stedfaſtneſſe Heb. 6.18 in Chriſt.
Q. How mean you?

A. Not withſtanding 2 Cor. 12.9. grievous temptations
and ſufferings in the fleſh.
Q. Sect. 7 Shal Faith, and Hope, be for ever?
Q. To what ſhal they give place?
A. To ibid. Love.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Becauſe ibid. its more excellent.
Q. How ſo?
A. It Eph. 3.29. was before either.
Q. How doth that appear?
A. The Eph. 3.17 root they grow upon, is love.
Q. What love muſt this be?
A. God 1 Joh, 4.16. himſelf, [as love] or God [his love].
Q. How conſidered?
A. As ſhed abroad Rom 5.5, in our hearts.
Q. By what means?
A. By ibid. the holy Spirit.
Q. How doth God [as love] or God [his love] appear?
A. In 1 Ioh. 4.10. Chriſt.
Q. How elſe is love more excellent, then eitheir faith, or hope?
A. They 1 Ioh. 4.17. are terminated (or end) in love.
Q. How ſo?
A. Love 1 Cor. 13.13. is the perfection (or complement) of both.
Q. As how?
A. That 1 Ioh. 4, 8, 9. which faith beleevs, and that which hope layes hold on, is love.
Q. How mean you?
A. Love Ioh. 3.16 in all the expreſsions of it.
Q. What are thoſe expreſsions?

A. Glory Rom. 2., honor, and immortality: All manner of Spirituall bleſsings in Eph. 1.3 heavenly things in Chriſt Jeſus 1 Cor, 2.9.; ſuch as eye hath not ſeen, nor ear heard; neither hath it entred into the heart of man, to conceive, thoſe things that are prepared for
them, that in (Gods love) love God, but God hath revealed them to us, by the ib. v. 10. Spirit, which alone ſearcheth, thoſe deep things of God, &c.
Q. What operation, hath theſe Queſtions, and Anſwers on you?
A. I have loſt Can. 8.6 my ſelf in love.
A. The love 1 Ioh 3.1 of God.
Q. How appearing?
A. In Ioh 3.16 Chriſt.
Q. What do you then?
A. Heb. 4.3. Reſt.
Q. And what then?
A. Eph. 3: 18, 18, 20. Admire.

div.head: A hint of the nature of the Kingdome of God, as it is even now, to Faith, and is alone for memory ſake, thus expreſt, as it was occaſioned, by, and given in to, a doubting Chriſtian, who for conſolation, demanded the ſcope, and myſterie of 2 Tim. 2.13.

lg.l: If you demand, twice fifty lines are here,
In which Gods Kingdome, doth moſt plaine appeare.

l.hi: If we beleeve not, The Scripture. yet he abideth faithfull, he cannot deny himſelf.

lg.l: YOu that the meaning ſeek, of this one verſe,
I ſhall the ſame, in theſe few words, rehearſe;
Gods power, and our weakneſſe, here you may ſee,
Both joyn'd together, in rich unity:
Our emptineſſe doth here, moſt plain appear;
Gods fulneſſe too, is here ſet downe, that fear,
Might not o're-whelme our hearts, and us diſmay:
For God Almighty is to ſave, alway.
Tho thus it be with us, that we miſgive,
That truth it ſelf ſometimes, we do'nt beleeve,
Yet God is faithfull, and the ſame for ever:
Our ſins and fears, and doubts, cannot us ſever;
For all that did us both, once come between,
Chriſt nayled on the Croſſe, moſt faſt I ween;
And what on earth is meet, for us to have,
That he will give to us, with faith to crave;
Gods Covenant is this, the Scriptures ſhow,
He for us nothing now, hath left to doe:
And tho to fleſh and blood it be moſt ſtrange;
Yet bleſt be they, that ſee this happy change,
Leave off then, caring for your ſelfe, and ſee,
Chriſt Ieſus will of you, moſt carefull be:
For, now, the name of God is this, I'm ſure,
Emmanuel, Chriſt, Godwith us, moſt pure.
If this be then his Name, what is more ſweet,
Or more welcome, then thoſe moſt comely feet,
That on the Mountains come, to tel that newes,
That God with us, his dwelling now doth chuſe?
Oh then once thinke not this glad tydings ſuch,
That for us to beleeve it, 't were too much:
Yea this of Faith's the root, for this is truth,
And for this end, ev'n God himſelfe came forth,
Was manifeſt in fleſh, our ſin to kill:
And ſo his pretious blood, did freely ſpill:
This is the Name of God, a Saviour true.
Who thinke not thus of him, they do'nt him know,
And tho there be that ſay, they doe him know;
They lye, if ſtill on earth, they live below.
For to this end, our Lord, came from above,
That he might raiſe our hearts, to him in love:
Yea to this end he came, and dwelt on earth,
That we in Heaven, might have enduring wealth:
Yea, us this day himſelfe, is come among,
That we might joy in him, with joy moſt ſtrong:
Then doe not thinke, that he with works is pleas'd,
That hath us from, all bondage, fully eas'd,
And made us free in Heaven, to dwel on high;
For he that rays'd us, now to faith is nigh.
But what's the life, which we by faith doe live,
A life beneath, what he himſelfe doth give?
Or is that life, which Chriſt himſelf hath given;
A life beneath, what he himſelfe hath liven?
No, he's our life, for ſo the Scriptures ſay,
I am the truth, the life, beſides the way.
If this be ſo, as plaine it doth papear,
Then let not unbeliefe, make you to feare,
But rather now in Chriſt, be ever bold,
Sith God doth ſo himſelfe, to us unfold:
For he's now one with us, and wee with him
Are one, which is our garment, white and trim:
What elſe is this, but that which Chriſt hath ſe'd,
I will be with you ſtill, and will you lead
Into the path of life, that we to heaven
Might fly, ſith Chriſt hath quite us now bereaven
Or earth and ſin, of hell and curſe together,
That we on Eagles wings might haſten thither,
And there make our aboad with Chriſt above,
Sith to this he hath called us in love.
If Chriſt be there, we alſo ſhould be there;
For by him now out foes all conquered are:
Yea this is certaine, the way's made moſt plaine:
All that is left by him, was ſurely ſlaine:
Why then be not affraid, ſith all is dead,
Which hath the world to deſtruction led,
Alive we are in Chriſt, our ſinne is gone,
And alwayes we now ſing in Mount Sion:
This is that high, and lofty, hill of God,
Where Chriſt now reigns, with his triumphant rod.
This is that hill, that makes all hils to quake,
And doth (this day) their great Foundations ſhake:
For why its true, that Chriſt hath undermin'd
This vaine worlds pride, as we in Goſpel find.
Nay to the Saints, this world doth ceaſe to be,
From Heaven alone is now, their pedigree:
New birth, new life, they're al together new,
New creatures all, as Scriptures plainly ſhew,
New earth, new heaven, and new Ieruſalem,
The ſtate and glory is, of theſe new men.
A new world too, ev'n that which is to come,
VVhich here beſides, the portion is of ſome,
Beleevers all, this world doe constitute,
Which doth mans carnall doctrine, quite confute;
This is that world, that ſhall at length appeare,
Beauteous, rich, and like to Christal clear:
This is that Kingdome, which we pray may come,
This is Gods Covenant, that perfect one,
This he will keep, tho we ev'n doubtfull, are,
There is no reaſon, why we it ſhould feare.
